title: Anxiety and depression among Canadian undergraduates with decreased sound tolerance
text:
Using a large primary dataset of Canadian undergraduates (N = 2,095), we show that those with clinically significant levels of the auditory perception disorder misophonia score higher on measures of depression (δ = .61) and anxiety (δ = .63) than those with non-clinical misophonia. This effect holds for hyperacusis, another auditory perception disorder: as hyperacusis severity increases, so does anxiety (ρ = .52) and depression (ρ = .41).



Undergraduates from Wilfrid Laurier University completed various questionnaires. They completed the Duke Misophonia Questionnaire (DMQ; Rosenthal et al., 2021), the Duke-Vanderbilt Misophonia Questionnaire (DVMQ; Williams et al., 2022), the Inventory of Hyperacusis Symptoms (IHS; Greenberg & Carlos, 2018), the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI; Beck, 1961), and the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI; Beck et al., 1988).
We then explored how their self-reported misophonia and hyperacusis levels correlated with their self-reported depression and anxiety levels. We employed non-parametric analyses of variance (ANOVA; Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test) and correlations (Spearman’s ρ).
To evaluate our effects, we mainly relied on effect size measures since null hypothesis significance testing will yield p < .05 when N is large (in our case, N = 2,095).



The investigation of how DST subcategories correlate with mental health difficulties was timely since psychometrically validated measures of misophonia have recently been developed (DMQ and DVMQ), yet their relation to depression and anxiety had not been explored.
Understanding how these aligned measures mapped onto mental health struggles can help highlight intervention strategies that can perhaps be implemented by stakeholders in universities.



This work was conducted by myself and my colleagues in the Department of Psychology at Wilfrid Laurier University: Natalia Van Esch, a current MSc student, and Cognisant Lab director and Assistant Professor, Dr. Nichole E. Scheerer.
Other folks in the Cognisant Lab also provided helpful discussion and feedback on this project, undoubtedly increasing the quality of the work.



Smith, C. M., Van Esch, N., & Scheerer, N. E. (2026). Anxiety and depression among Canadian undergraduates with decreased sound tolerance. Hearing Research, 471, 109522. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.heares.2025.109522



Beck, A. T. (1961). An inventory for measuring depression. Archives of General Psychiatry, 4(6), 561. https://doi.org/10.1001/archpsyc.1961.01710120031004
Beck, A. T., Epstein, N., Brown, G., & Steer, R. A. (1988). An inventory for measuring clinical anxiety: Psychometric properties. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 56(6), 893–897. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-006X.56.6.893
Greenberg, B., & Carlos, M. (2018). Psychometric properties and factor structure of a new scale to measure hyperacusis: Introducing the Inventory of Hyperacusis Symptoms. Ear & Hearing, 39(5), 1025–1034. https://doi.org/10.1097/AUD.0000000000000583
Rosenthal, M. Z., Anand, D., Cassiello-Robbins, C., Williams, Z. J., Guetta, R. E., Trumbull, J., & Kelley, L. D. (2021). Development and initial validation of the Duke Misophonia Questionnaire. Frontiers in Psychology, 12. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2021.709928
Williams, Z. J., Cascio, C. J., & Woynaroski, T. G. (2022). Psychometric validation of a brief self-report measure of misophonia symptoms and functional impairment: The duke-vanderbilt misophonia screening questionnaire. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 897901. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2022.897901

title: The effect of visual angle on slot machine gambling in virtual reality
text:
Read my undergraduate thesis here!


Check out my poster from SOBDR 2025 here!


What did we do?
This research project comprises my undergraduate thesis at Wilfrid Laurier University.
This work was conducted explored how modifying the low-level stimulus property visual angle alters gambling behaviours when using a virtual reality slot machine.
We argue that although visual angle does not appear to affect gambling in VR, the behavioural impacts of other low-level stimulus features (e.g., colour, brightness) should be explored so that gamblers’ decision-making is not exploited through simple stimulus manipulations.


How did we do it?
Undergraduates from Wilfrid Laurier University completed an experiment wherein they gambled using a virtual reality slot machine that had both a high and low visual angle.
Participants wore a physiological tracker, the EmotiBit, which approximated autonomic arousal through measurements of heart rate variability, galvanic skin conductance, skin conductance responses, heart rate, and more.
Gambling persistence (gambling past a specified end-point), and post-reinforcement pauses (time taken between each spin of the slot machine) were the dependent variables.


Why did we do it?
This research draws on a classic theory from Dr. Antonio Damasio, a neuroscientist who postulated that arousal influences decision-making (Damasio, 1996). This theory originates from his work with frontal-brain-damaged patients who showed decision deficiencies during economic games, which supposedly stemmed from inadequate arousal levels (Damasio, 1996).
We hypothesized that participants who experienced greater autonomic arousal would make better gambling choices. The slot machine’s visual angle was the purported mechanism by which autonomic arousal would change, such that higher visual angles lead to higher levels of arousal, and vice versa (e.g., Gall & Latoschik, 2023).
Other work has explored the role of visual angle’s influence on behaviour, but had not used an adequate gambling measure to assess how arousal may alter gambling (e.g., Oberdörfer et al., 2023). We aimed to fill these gaps.


Who contributed?
This study was conducted by myself and my undergraduate advisor, Dr. Nichole E. Scheerer. Dr. Scheerer is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Psychology and director of the Cognisant Lab at Wilfrid Laurier University.


References
Damasio, A. (1996). The somatic marker hypothesis and the possible functions of the prefrontal cortex. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B: Biological Sciences. https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/abs/10.1098/rstb.1996.0125
Gall, D., & Latoschik, M. E. (2020). Visual angle modulates affective responses to audiovisual stimuli. Computers in Human Behavior, 109, 106346. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chb.2020.106346
Oberdörfer, S., Birnstiel, S., Steinhaeusser, S. C., & Latoschik, M. E. (2023). An Approach to Investigate an Influence of Visual Angle Size on Emotional Activation During a Decision-Making Task. In J. Y. C. Chen & G. Fragomeni (Eds.), Virtual, Augmented and Mixed Reality (Vol. 14027, pp. 649–664). Springer Nature Switzerland. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-35634-6_47

title: Test Project 2

title: About
text:
ResearchGate
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Google Scholar
  
  
    
     Github
  

      
Hello, I’m Carter.
I am an MA candidate in Cognitive Psychology at the University of Waterloo, where I study in Dr. Clara Colombatto’s Vision and Cognition Laboratory.
My current research examines the low-level cues that humans observe in social interactions, which may let them infer things about others (e.g., intentions). Further, I explore how these cues may influence an observers’ cognition (e.g., their attention).
In the past, I have studied the auditory conditions misophonia and hyperacusis and their association with depression and anxiety. I have also worked with virtual reality to explore how modifying stimulus properties (e.g., slot machine size) alters gambling behaviours.
I am passionate about philosophy, cycling, music, and the Toronto Blue Jays.
Please feel free to contact me at: carter.smith@uwaterloo.ca.
Check out my research

title: Anxiety and depression among Canadian undergraduates with decreased sound tolerance
text:
Using a large primary dataset of Canadian undergraduates (N = 2,095), we show that those with clinically significant levels of the auditory perception disorder misophonia score higher on measures of depression (δ = .61) and anxiety (δ = .63) than those with non-clinical misophonia. This effect holds for hyperacusis, another auditory perception disorder: as hyperacusis severity increases, so does anxiety (ρ = .52) and depression (ρ = .41).



Undergraduates from Wilfrid Laurier University completed various questionnaires. They completed the Duke Misophonia Questionnaire (DMQ; Rosenthal et al., 2021), the Duke-Vanderbilt Misophonia Questionnaire (DVMQ; Williams et al., 2022), the Inventory of Hyperacusis Symptoms (IHS; Greenberg & Carlos, 2018), the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI; Beck, 1961), and the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI; Beck et al., 1988).
We then explored how their self-reported misophonia and hyperacusis levels correlated with their self-reported depression and anxiety levels. We employed non-parametric analyses of variance (ANOVA; Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test) and correlations (Spearman’s ρ).
To evaluate our effects, we mainly relied on effect size measures since null hypothesis significance testing will yield p < .05 when N is large (in our case, N = 2,095).



The investigation of how DST subcategories correlate with mental health difficulties was timely since psychometrically validated measures of misophonia have recently been developed (DMQ and DVMQ), yet their relation to depression and anxiety had not been explored.
Understanding how these aligned measures mapped onto mental health struggles can help highlight intervention strategies that can perhaps be implemented by stakeholders in universities.



This work was conducted by myself and my colleagues in the Department of Psychology at Wilfrid Laurier University: Natalia Van Esch, a current MSc student, and Cognisant Lab director and Assistant Professor, Dr. Nichole E. Scheerer.

title: Anxiety and depression among Canadian undergraduates with decreased sound tolerance
text:
New esearch in Hearing Research

What did we do?
Using a large primary dataset of Canadian undergraduates (N = 2,095), we show that those with clinically significant levels of the auditory perception disorder misophonia score higher on measures of depression (δ = .61) and anxiety (δ = .63) than those with non-clinical misophonia. This effect holds for hyperacusis, another auditory perception disorder: as hyperacusis severity increases, so does anxiety (ρ = .52) and depression (ρ = .41).


How did we do it?
Undergraduates from Wilfrid Laurier University completed various questionnaires. They completed the Duke Misophonia Questionnaire (DMQ), the Duke-Vanderbilt Misophonia Questionnaire (DVMQ), the Inventory of Hyperacusis Symptoms (IHS), the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), and the Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI).
We then explored how their self-reported misophonia and hyperacusis levels correlated with their self-reported depression and anxiety levels. We employed non-parametric analyses of variance (ANOVA; Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test) and correlations (Spearman’s ρ).
To evaluate our effects, we mainly relied on effect size measures since null hypothesis significance testing will yield p < .05 when N is large (in our case, N = 2,095).


Why did we do it?
The investigation of how DST subcategories correlate with mental health difficulties was timely since psychometrically validated measures of misophonia have recently been developed (DMQ and DVMQ), yet their relation to depression and anxiety had not been explored.
Understanding how these aligned measures mapped onto mental health struggles can help highlight intervention strategies that can perhaps be implemented by stakeholders in universities.


Who contributed?
This work was conducted by myself and my colleagues in the Department of Psychology at Wilfrid Laurier University: Natalia Van Esch, a current MSc student, and Cognisant Lab director and Assistant Professor, Dr. Nichole E. Scheerer.
Other folks in the Cognisant Lab also provided helpful discussion and feedback on this project, undoubtedly increasing the quality of the work.
